documents.document:
I’ve been struggling with writers block lately. Actually, struggling is an understatement. And “lately” means a really long time.

I’ve found that when the weather is gloomy and gray, it’s a lot harder for me to be inspired. But, now that it’s spring (well, you know, supposed to be spring…it’s actually still snowing…) and the sunshine is starting to peek through the clouds a bit more every day. Hopefully the inspiration will start to flow again.

It’s hard to get out of a writer’s block rut. And I’ve come to the conclusion that you just need to get your head in the game and the weather outside shouldn’t have anything to do with being inspired, because there are plenty of other places  inspiration can be found.

  • Workout. I love going to the gym to run or swim. It’s “me” time and I can get my mind focused on one thing when I run. It helps me come up with so many ideas for blog posts (this one, actually!), homework and blog design. it really helps. Plus, it gives me endorphins and makes me feel oh-so-good. There’s also that benefit about working out being good for your health, too.
  • Read. I read blogs and news sites daily and by doing this I’ve come up with great ideas for my own blog posts. The more I read, the more inspired I get. And, it’s a good way to get your imagination flowing.
  • Music. An absolute must-do. Music helps me destress and the less I’m stressed, the more creative I get. It’s a beautiful thing.
  • Talk it out. My writer’s block ended (for the most part) this time after talking to some of my favorite PR friends via Twitter. They helped me brainstorm some fun topics for blog posts and come up with ways to beat my writer’s block. Talking it out, for more than just writer’s block, is a great way to stop stressing and start writing.
  • Social media. Social media is a never ending inspiration machine. When I see posts that other people write and see the things that they’re doing – I get beyond inspired. Taking 10 minutes to scroll through Facebook, a blog reader or Twitter can really just generate a lot of great ideas. Don’t comment, don’t “like”…just read.

I’ve wanted to work in the entertainment industry for as long as I can remember. I wanted to be a pop star like Britney Spears when I was 13 until I realized that I couldn’t sing or dance. So, that wasn’t gonna happen.

When I was a sophomore in college I wanted to go into entertainment law. But now that I’ve found my calling in social media and public relations, I want to do publicity for celebrities or just in the music industry in general.

Sadly, I don’t live in New York, Los Angeles or even Nashville where the music industry has a huge presence. So, if you’re like me and want to work in entertainment PR, you’re left wondering: “How am I supposed to do this?”

Well, here are some ways you can get some experience in an industry that, unless you know somebody, will keep you out without legitimate and good experience.

  • Intern at local music venues and music festivals. Where I live in Ann Arbor, Mich. we have a ton of music venues all over the place. Chances are an internship at any of these places will be unpaid, but the experience will be priceless. There’s also this cool music/entertainment festival in Ann Arbor – The Ann Arbor Summer Festival and/or “Top of the Park” where i’m in the process of learning about internship opportunities. And these small opportunities can add up to a lot.
  • Write, write, write! One of my favorite ways to break into the entertainment industry is by simply writing. Freelance for local arts magazines or writing for the entertainment section of your school’s newspaper is a great way to get your name out into the industry and meet people, too.
  • Work with local bands or musicians. Working with local artists is a great way to get experience. While, again, this is probably going to be a volunteer kinda thing without pay, it’s a great way to see what it’s like to work with artists. And you’re going to learn a LOT.
  • Become a radio star. Never rule out radio stations – they offer a lot of indirect music industry experience, and it’s a great way to network and meet the pros who are responsible for the biggest part of music: putting those tunes out for the fans to hear!
  • Think outside the box. There are so many other great ways to get entertainment industry experience. Volunteer to do social media for a theater or plan an on campus battle of the bands event. The more you do now, the more you’ll be rewarded in the future. Also, check out professional organizations like PRSA or IABC – chances are you can meet someone who works in entertainment somehow, or at least knows somebody who does!

In case you missed my incessant Tweets for the past month (who am I kidding, probably the last two months) , today is…oh, wait. Are you ready for this? Are you sure? Really, really sure? You might be sure, but can you handle it? Really, truly handle it? I know, you are sure. And I get it, you can handle it. I hear ya.

Today is my birthday!

And like every girl ever, I love my birthday. I don’t like the getting older part, but a day dedicated to me is pretty awesome.

The thing I don’t like about my birthday (other than inching another year closer to 30) is when people ask me what I want.

Well, I want to be a princess. And to marry Justin Timberlake. How about the Hope Diamond?  I want (and obviously I totally need!) all of those things. As a PR professional, there are many things I need that I just hate buying for myself.


  • Pens. I love colorful pens. I love them a lot. I use them to color code my planner. I use colors when editing so my copy editing marks stand out. And I use them to write “thank you” notes to colleagues, reporters and friends. They make boring black and white copy much more fun to look at and deal with.
  • Notebooks. I’m kind of obsessed with notebooks. I don’t really need more, but I buy them all the time. Especially when I love the cover or the spacing inside the notebooks. They’re useful to have at work when I need to jot down phone messages or notes. I’m really bad at wasting sticky notes for a quick message, so notebooks are great for me to use. They allow for more space to write and keep everything together in one spot. Plus, you never know when a random meeting will be sprung on you and you need to grab a notebook and pen.
  • Gift cards. This should probably say “Starbucks gift cards,” but I don’t drink coffee. Yep, that’s right. I’m a public relations professional who doesn’t drink or even like coffee (I find I get better results with ice water than I do with caffeine )! So, gift cards to other places like Subway, local restaurants, and the Apple Store (or iTunes!) are always great. I’m not saying I wouldn’t use a Starbucks card (I * love * their vanilla bean frap!), it’s just that other places make more sense for me. Also great: J.Crew, Banana Republic, DSW, Target, Aldo and LOFT. Because a girl can never have too many cute clothes for work!
  • Picture frames. Picture frames are kinda like notebooks to me…I have way too many that I don’t use, and I can’t stop buying them. Especially at Target. Target has the cutest picture frames. I cover my work area with pictures of my family, so some lovely frames are always nice to have around.

Any special gifts you like to get on your birthday?

Twitter is one of the many tools that students and professionals can use to brand themselves. If you’re reading this, chances are you’ve been told over and over again how to properly Tweet, when to RT and how to engage with professionals and other students through Twitter chats.

Well, those things are all well and good…and they’re important. But, something someone said to me recently got me thinking: how often are those rules really followed? It’s like being taught best practices in the classroom, but learning that something is done completely different in the real world.



So, here are three things I’ve learned about Twitter. Hopefully, they can help you, too.

  • BE TRANSPARENT: OK, here’s a pet-peeve: you upload a very nice, professional picture on Twitter, you fill out an amazing bio about yourself…and then you make your Twitter private. Why? You shouldn’t have anything to hide. If you’re being appropriate, relevant and professional, don’t make your Twitter private. In public relations, we must advise our clients to always, always, always be transparent. Why wouldn’t you do the same for yourself?
  • BE A RESEARCHER: Sometimes its hard to find interesting people to follow on Twitter, especially when you’re already following a ton of already interest people and want to learn something new. Here’s something I do: I figure out who the most relevant and fun people are in an industry I’m interested in. For example – entertainment. I connected with this cool guy from MTV on Twitter and something I do to meet more cool people in the entertainment PR and social media industry is look through his followers and the people he follows.  No, this isn’t creepy. It isn’t Facebook; I’m not looking through someone’s friends to see who I can add from high school as a friend to “stalk.” To be in PR, you need to know how to research. Research for yourself, too.
  • BE YOURSELF: Just because you shouldn’t post about all those crazy parties to attend and the not-so-appropriate other things you and your friends discuss, doesn’t by any means you should express yourself on social media. Talk about your adventures if you love to travel. Discuss those amazing recipes you tried last weekend or the great restaurant you went to during restaurant week if you’re a foodie. And, if music is your thing, you shouldn’t be afraid to support your favorite musicians. Tweeting about these things can create really amazing connections for you. I know that my love for music, celebrities and all things pop culture have opened some really great doors for me and I’ve been some really cool people through Twitter. As my favorite singer once said, “Be bold, be creative, be expressive and be proud of who you are.”

PR girls possess certain qualities that make them pretty fabulous and excellent at their job.

Even though, according to NYC PR Girls (but who can argue with them), we constantly have work on our minds, know how to dig for information, pay attention to every detail and aren’t afraid to speak our minds, these certain qualities are what also make that PR girl great at building strong, wonderful relationships.


PR Girls…
  • Are loyal. Since our relationships are our top priorities, and our job involves satisfying the needs of multiple people, we need to stay loyal and dedicated to making sure those relationships become and/or stay strong, delightful and genuine.
  • Are dedicated. We work hard for our clients so of course we work hard on our relationship with you. Even with all those long hours, we know how important personal relationships are and we never forget to pay special attention to our sweetheart.
  • Know the best places in town. Even with all that hard work we put in, we love to have fun, try new things and will never plan a boring date.
  • Stay positive. When faced with a problem we will always look for, and find, a solution. We always put full effort into everything we do.
  • Are efficient. From our incredibly packed schedules to our never-ending to-do lists to all the people we need to stay in touch with on a regular basis PR gals need to stay extremely organized and keep track of everything.
  • Text/call back right away. With our smartphones basically glued to our hands and {as mentioned above} staying in touch with numerous people at all times, we are predisposed to {and ready} to respond as quickly as possible.

What would you add?



Guest post by Rachel Laitala of RachMariePR.

This week has been an interesting one for me at my work/internships. I’ve spent a lot of time this week printing copies of resumes and cover letters for jobs (in addition to making dozens of copies of each resume, too, of course!).

During this activity, I came across a ton of things that just drove me crazy about resumes and cover letters. And I’d like to share all of this knowledge I was bestowed upon this week with all of you! This might come off quite…well, mean…but hopefully humorous.


So, on your resume…

  • No, you don’t need a picture…headshot…modeling…family photo…or otherwise. OK, you’re proud of the way you look. That’s great. YOUR PICTURE DOES NOT BELONG ON YOUR RESUME. You aren’t applying for a modeling contract here, people, you’re applying for an internship/job with a respected institution. Take the modeling shot off, clean up your resume and be professional. If they really want to see what you look like, they can checkout your LinkedIn, various social media accounts or wait until the interview.
  • Spell your name correctly. Uhm, do I really need to say this? Watching out for typos is an obvious thing, but when the spelling of your name on your resume is completely different from the spelling of your name on your cover letter, there’s clearly a problem. Also spelling your nAmE lIkE tHiS…probably not a good idea…
  • Spell the name of the person you are addressing the cover letter to correctly. You aren’t going to win any brownie points with the hiring committee if you misspell the name of the person you’re addressing your cover letter to. Plus, your resume will probably be accidentally misplaced in the trashcan.
  • Spelling in general. You know how I feel about spelling your name correctly, but make sure you spell every other word in your resume and cover letter correctly, too. Sick of reading them over? Have family, friends, coworkers, professors, internship supervisors and whatever other smarties are in your life read them over for you. Spelling and grammar errors can result in a big ‘ole NO.
  • Practice what you preach. This kinda relates back to the spelling thing. If you write “I’m excellent at copy editing and grammar…” in your resume/cover letter, yet it’s full of mistakes, what is the hiring committee supposed to think? If you can’t get your own brand together, how can you help get a company’s brand together? (Of course, with my luck, this blog post is probably full of spelling and grammar errors…)
  • If the only experience you’ve ever had is at a restaurant… One resume I looked at had one PR internship listed followed by two pages of restaurant experience. That’s just fine and dandy, but if that’s all the experience you’ve had and you’re applying for a PR internship you don’t need two pages of restaurants you’ve worked at since high school. Your resume should only be one page. Focus on the good things at that one PR internship and then relate your most recent (no more than two or three) restaurant jobs to PR. And, if you're applying for a top executive position, probably not gonna happen.
  • Fonts. And font sizes. They should match. Really. It’s OK to get creative (as long as you’re not way out there!) and add a clear, yet fun, font to you resume. But you should have on your resume a maximum of (maybe) two fonts. And don’t have a million different font sizes either. Keep it simple, keep it clean, keep it readable!
  • Family! We all love our families – that’s amazing and wonderful. But your family doesn’t belong on your resume. Plus, the HR people aren’t even allowed to legally ask about family when interviewing you. Introduce your family to your job after you’re hired.

Alright, so earlier this week I lashed out at unfortunate stereotypes about PR girls that have nothing to do with who I am or who I want to be. So, today, I'm doing just the opposite. I'm telling you which stereotypes fit me to a "T."

  • I am not addicted to social media and my phone. I am beyond obsessed with my phone. And Twitter. And always being connected. If my phone isn't within reach, I panic. Probably not a good thing, and I have a feeling I may need therapy to cure this ailment. But, I don't care. I love being connected and I love being social. I love knowing what's going on...I like to know how things are going to turn out...from start to finish.
  • I'm not a workaholic. I feel like I'm at my best when I'm busy, busy, busy! It makes me feel in control and it makes me feel accomplished. The more I have to do, the happier I am with myself - personally and professionally. I know, it's weird. But I live for chaos. Well, organized chaos.
  • I don't love to travel. Even traveling in the car from Ann Arbor to Detroit gets my adrenaline going. To say I have wanderlust is the biggest understatement ever. Get me on an airplane and I'm off the wall with excitement. If I could travel every day and still work in PR, I would. Maybe there is a job like that somewhere. Anywhere? Please?

You’ve heard the stereotypes about PR girls, right? You know, how they all drink coffee, love to party, spend most of their time chatting on the phone or Internet, etc.

Well, I’m here to tell you that not all PR girls fit those stereotypes. And it isn’t that there is anything wrong with those stereotypes, because honestly, they aren’t really bad per sey, but I just want to let you all know that I…

  • I (don’t) love coffee! Most PR girls I know love coffee, but I can’t stand coffee (also it’s not just PR girls that love coffee though…most crazy busy professions are all about drinking the coffee). I’d much rather have a nice, tall glass of ice cold water. So good. Coffee just tastes so gross. But, for the record, I do enjoy a mocha frap from Starbucks every so often, though lately I’ve been only ordering a vanilla bean frap from the coffee chain. Seriously, so good. But, back to water – so good and it keeps me hydrated. What more do I need from a drink?
  • I am so (not) super stylish! Most PR girls are fashionistas, but I am not one of them. Confession: I am too Midwest to have style. When I’m not at work, I’m all about jeans, t-shirts, flip flops and ponytails.. That’s not to say I don’t have my stylish moments, because I’m sure I do, and I love reading fashion mags as much as the next girl, but wearing the latest runway looks has never been my thing. I’ve never understood the point of making sure every hair is in place or caking my face with makeup. Also: I don’t wear high heels. I fall down when I wear them.
  • I totally love to party (in my PJs) every weekend! Sure, I love to hang out with my friends and family, but I’m not a super social butterfly who goes to every awesome party every weekend. I’m a homebody. I’ve never enjoyed going to bars and clubs, and instead I prefer sitting at home with a chick flick and a pizza. That’s not to say that I don’t enjoy a good party every so often, but I’m much more laid back than most.

As passionate future PR professionals, we take great pride in our schoolwork and internships. A lot of us spend a lot of time on our personal brands through social media or blogging.

But, believe it or not, there are some other things you should be doing before you graduate to make you an even more desirable job candidate.

Obviously, having experience through internships and that degree are the most important, but there are some other skills you should have to impress potential employers, too.

Via
Coding. It’s kind of tedious to think about coding. You know, HTML or CSS or the even fancier stuff. I’m not saying you have to be a professional coder, but knowing the basics of HTML and CSS can go along way on a resume and in an interview.

Adobe. I don’t mean Acrobat (though, there are some things you should know how to do!). I’m talking about Photoshop. InDesign. Illustrator. DreamWeaver. These are all beyond helpful – personally and professionally. If you can use any of these with basic understanding, you’re on your way.

Photography. We can’t all be Annie Leibovitz or Randee St. Nicholas, but being able to take decent pictures at events is a skill that not many people have. Even being able to whip out your iPhone at a moments notice and taking a picture for a press release is something some people just can’t do.

Why are these skills so important?

Because they make us more well-rounded job candidates and offer expertise to roles that other people might not be able to bring. Even a weekend course on any of these subjects can go a long way.

What skills have you mastered to make you a more desirable job candidate?

As you know, I recently redesigned my blog. I thought I'd share with you my new branding.

I chose the colors gray and pink as well as gold glitter because I think they're a good representation of who I am. My styles are so diverse. I like shabby chic, midwestern simplicity and, above all, I love classic beauty. So, I kind of mixed it all together.

I used the fonts KG Eyes Wide Open and Calibri.

One of my favorite friends in the world, Rachel, has nominated me for a Liebster Award! Hooray! I'll be honest with you, my blogs have received the Liebster Award in the past, but since this is the first blog I'm actually keeping up with, I'm going to post it anyway.

(She actually nominated my other blog, but this is going to be posted there, too, maybe. I just have more readers here...I think.)

"The Liebster Award is given by fellow bloggers to new blogs with smaller followings, but with huge potential. It's a great way to find new blogs as well as support one another." Liebster is a word with German origins and has several definitions: dearest, sweetest, kindest, nicest, beloved, lovely, kind, pleasant, valued, cute, endearing, welcome and sweetheart.



The rules of the Liebster Award are as follows:
  • Mention the person who nominated you with a link to their blog and about who they are and how you know them.
  • Answer the 11 questions they ask.
  • Nominate 11 other bloggers with a small following but with a lot of potential.
  • Create 11 of your own questions for them to answer.
  • Notify your nominees!

Here are the questions Rachel has asked me:

What are three things you can't live without? My teddy bear, my iPhone and my MacBook Pro. (I'm assuming people don't count as "things.")

Heels or flats? Flats. But, full disclosure here, I prefer to be barefoot.

Favorite book? Probably...'To Kill A Mocking Bird.'

Must-Have Beauty Item? I'm not a big makeup girl, but I'm a stickler for a good skin care regimen  I swear by Philosophy's Purity cleanser and their Hope in a Jar moisturizer.

Five words that describe you? Dedicated, passionate, anxious, flaky and poppy.

Guilty Pleasure? Oh, Lordy, let's see...probably late 90s bubblegum pop music. The lyrics can be beyond lame and cheesy, but nothing makes me happier or want to dance more.

Favorite fashion tred now: Ha! No idea. I'm not much of a fashionista. 

What one superpower would you choose to have? The ability to time travel. 

Dream job? Britney Spears' PR girl. Or being Britney herself. Or anything where I get to work with her.
Favorite piece of clothing your closet right now? Uhm, yoga pants...

Something your readers don't know about you? I've had surgery twice in my life. Once in 2001 when I had my tonsils removed (I was 15!) and then again, 10 years later, in 2011 when I had my galbladder removed on my birthday (I was 26.)

Here are the bloggers I'm nominating (there are less than 11 because Rachel stole all the bloggers I know!):

Olivia Adams PR
One Heel Ahead
Faith and Gasoline
Just Georgia Peachy
It's My Life
Girl With a Banjo
Vivian Lee
City Girl Hanna
uPRise PR
Stories and Scripts

And, here are your 11 questions:

1. If you could meet one person from history (someone who is no longer with us), who would it be and why?
2. What's your favorite dessert?
3. What's your favorite sport?
4. If you could trade places with an animal for a day, what animal would it be and why?
5. What's the coolest place you've ever visited?
6. Can you speak another language?
7. Share a secret with me!
8. What's the temperature where you live right now? 
9. What is your dream job?
10. What is your favorite music genre?
11. What's your favorite thing about blogging?

These days, getting a job is as much about who you know as about what you know. Infact, sometimes, who you know can be more important than what you know.

I have a bit of social anxiety and can be very shy and awkward around people I don’t know and tend to be a little more inward at networking events. But did you know that Twitter is a great tool to do a little bit of “pre-networking”?

There have been numerous times that I’ve been at events and have seen people who I “know” through Twitter, but have been too shy to introduce myself. Mostly because I haven’t spent much time talking to them on the social network and I’m afraid they won’t remember or recognized me.

But, for those who I have been fortunate enough to crawl out of my shell and actually meet (Hi, Jason Mollica!), it was one of the best things I ever did for myself.

Meeting your Twitter connections in person just solidifies a great relationship with these people – whether they’re mentors or friends. Heck – even family (I have cousins on Facebook that I’ve never meet in real life!)

So, what are some ways you can ensure that you’ll be able to meet these people face-to-face after only speaking to them? Check out a few below…

via
Interact! A casual “hello” or commenting on a link isn’t going to help you out here. You need to interact with them and your shared interests (sports, music, technology, whatever). If they’re someone who reaches out to students to help them a lot, take their advice and tell them how it helped you. Have real conversations with substance instead of a few “thank yous” or “that was cool” responses. It won’t help you overcome the shyness, I promise.

Join in Twitter chats! Sometimes, the most inspirational people host Twitter chats where you can interact with them on a more professional level and share your thoughts and experiences if you’re unsure of how to proceed on a one-on-one Twitter conversation. Plus, Twitter chats give you a great opportunity to “meet” other cool and inspiring people, too!

Ask if you can email them! If they can offer you advice, but 140 characters isn’t the way to do it, ask people if you can email them. If they’re really willing to help, they won’t say no! Building a relationship with people is important and shouldn’t be done just on Twitter. Emails, phone calls and actually meeting people are important steps in the process, too!

I don't have much to say today, but I have read a lot this week and I thought I'd share some of my favorite links with you this morning.

So, grab a coffee, tea or your morning beverage of choice, a comfy chair and cozy blanket and get to reading some of this great articles from the week.


via
  • Valentine's Day is just a month away and believe it or not, you can get some great media hits. Jamie Werner tells all about V-Day pitching tips on the PR Couture blog.
  • Ever been stuck in the elevator with someone and not sure what to say? Happens to me all the time and it's always the most awkward silence. Ever. It's kind of nerve-wracking to even think about! But, NYC PR Girls give some great pointers on how to make the most of that dreaded elevator chat.
  • Some of us are organized, some of us not so much. But, if you're looking to get more organized Rachel gathered some tips from her faves on how they stay organized. Some great tips here, make sure to check it out.
  • Are you stressed? I'm stressed. A lot. Personally and professionally. But, PR Daily has ideas on how you can cal that stress down in your professional life. And there are some pretty good thoughts here.
  • If you're in your 20s like me, you see those lists "XYZ to do in your 20s" and you're oh, dang, I'm really awful at life once you read them. Here's a list from Emily about five things that are killing your 20s. And it's more important that those other lists. Promise. 

Do you have any great reads that you want to share this morning?

Do you know how many blogs I've had in the past five years? Well, actually, let's scratch that question. Let's go with, do you know how many blog DESIGNS I've had in the past five years? A lot. I can count 10 off the top of my head. I know there are more.

Here's one more to add to the list.

I think it kind of has to do with the fact that I'm never satisfied. I always want something better for myself. Something prettier, something fresher, something more perfect. I kinda wish I was that way about other things in life - you know, like cleaning my apartment or my hot mess of hair.



I'm like that about a lot of things, though. A little bit OCD. OK, I admit, I'm very OCD (except about my messy apartment). I will probably have written and rewritten this blog post about half a dozen times. When I pour my heart and soul into something the whole world sees, I don't like it to not be as perfect as it can be. (The funny thing about that is though, that no matter how many times I edit this, I bet you $5 you'll find a typo. Because I'm not perfect and I like that about myself.)

I'm a real person, you know. I have feelings and passions and I have dislikes and annoyances. I don't like to hide myself. I share all of that about me with the world on social media and on my blogs. Yes, blogs. I have two of them. I have this blog - where I talk about public relations, social media, digital marketing, the life of a PR girl etc. And then I have my personal blog - a piece of me - where I talk about everything else.

There have been many times I've considered putting the two blogs together. And to be honest, maybe I should. One blog usually takes the back seat to the other. But I guess I just don't want to. And I don't know why.

One time, I had someone tell me - someone who isn't much older than me - they told me that the things I love and the things I'm passion about are going to cost me a job one day. Because the people "her" age look down upon those things.

And I almost lost it. I'd never been that close to yelling at someone. This is shocking, if you know me, because I avoid confrontation at all costs. I don't like fighting, I don't like awkward and angry moments. I just don't do it because I don't see the point.

I don't think I should have to hide what makes me happy. I shouldn't have to hide my family, my favorite sports teams, my idols and my world. If you don't like it, then you don't like it, but that shouldn't be a reason to not hire me. Liking a certain musician or football team who you do not happen to enjoy or cheer for doesn't make me any less qualified to do a job. That ignorance could be the biggest mistake of your life.

So here it is, here I am. I've hidden for a long time, I've decided to hide, but now I'm not going to do that anymore. I don't like it. I don't like walking on eggshells.

My name is Emily. I'll be 29 years old in April. I've cheered for and have loved the Michigan Wolverines, Detroit Red Wings/Lions/Tigers/Pistons since I was old enough to remember cheering for and loving them. Britney Spears is my idol - she's the one person in the world who has never let me down and has taught me to use my strengths against my weakness.



I find tomatoes to be absolutely disgusting, I like to run and swim, I think bacon and NYC are both overrated. I suffer from binge eating disorder, social anxiety and major depressive disorder. Sometimes it's hard to separate from those things. Not sometimes, most of the time, actually. I like to hunt and fish. I believe in the United States Constitution. I don't drink, I don't party, I don't swear and I don't do things that will get me in trouble...because I just don't. Never have, probably never will.

Most importantly, I believe in God and all the wonderful things in life he's given me. He blessed me with the seven most amazing beautiful nieces and nephews.

So, that's me. If you want to know more personal stuff about me, then head on over to my other blog. It's pretty fun over there. I'm kinda snarky and sarcastic. But also real. I have a lot of emotions and I go through a lot, but it's real. And if not, that's cool.

You can stay here and learn about me through my work and what I love. This is what I do, not who I am. Truth be told, who I am is a pretty great girl with a really big heart and (even though it's usually a hot mess) pretty great hair, too.

I'm not entirely sure why I'm typing this...I think I probably just needed to get some stuff of my chest. What I really wanted to say is I don't like when people hide. And I needed to explain why I'm so "Emily" on social media, I guess.

So...yeah. That's basically it. New blog (design), new year.

And I know it's gonna be a good one.
